container-title: the Committee on the Study of Religion (1987–90), the Committee on Middle Eastern Studies (1990–96), and the Foreign Cultures Area of the College Core Curriculum (1981–86). He has co-chaired the Allston Task Force on Undergraduate Life (2003–5), and served on the Arts and Sciences faculty council
note: He was also Allston Burr Senior Tutor (resident dean) in the John Winthrop House (undergraduate college) from 1975–77 and served as Master of Currier House (undergraduate college), from 1991–2003. Born William A. Graham, Jr., son of W. Albert and Evelyn Powell Graham, in Raleigh, North Carolina, in 1943, he was raised in Chapel Hill, North Carolina, and is a graduate of Chapel Hill High School (1961). He received his B.A. summa
title: Albertson Professor of Middle Eastern Studies in the Faculty of Arts and Sciences and John Lord O'Brian Professor of Divinity and Dean of the Divinity School at Harvard University. He has been a member of the Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences since 1973, with a joint appointment in the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations and the Committee on the Study of Religion. In 2002 he also joined the Faculty of Divinity as its dean and continues at present in that capacity. At Harvard he has served also as director of the Center for Middle Eastern Studies (1990–96) and chaired the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations (1997–2002
